channel.title: Comments on: A challenge to publishers to justify embargo periods

item.title: By: Compartes tu investigación en #OpenAccess pero ¿lo haces de forma legal? | Audeo Dicere
item.dc:creator: Compartes tu investigación en #OpenAccess pero ¿lo haces de forma legal? | Audeo Dicere
item.description: […] sus documentos autoguardados, “self-archiving”, en un repositorio público. (Sugiero este post de Jon Tennant donde trata este tema con mayor grado de […]
item.content:encoded: […] sus documentos autoguardados, “self-archiving”, en un repositorio público. (Sugiero este post de Jon Tennant donde trata este tema con mayor grado de […]

item.title: By: How to make your research 100% Open Access for free (and legally) – Green Tea and Velociraptors
item.dc:creator: How to make your research 100% Open Access for free (and legally) – Green Tea and Velociraptors
item.description: […] The important thing to note here is how to check journal policies through the Sherpa/Romeo tool, which is quite comprehensive. Some institutional repositories have inbuilt checks based on Sherpa/Romeo too, to make sure that your archiving efforts are journal-compliant. It’s also worth noting the existence of embargo periods, and challenging the need for them. […]
item.content:encoded: […] The important thing to note here is how to check journal policies through the Sherpa/Romeo tool, which is quite comprehensive. Some institutional repositories have inbuilt checks based on Sherpa/Romeo too, to make sure that your archiving efforts are journal-compliant. It’s also worth noting the existence of embargo periods, and challenging the need for them. […]

item.title: By: And the rich get richer.. – Green Tea and Velociraptors
item.dc:creator: And the rich get richer.. – Green Tea and Velociraptors
item.description: […] articles in Science can be self-archived immediately upon publication anyway, or after a six month embargo, including uploaded to PubMed Central. That means all the peer-reviewed science, minus the fancy […]
item.content:encoded: […] articles in Science can be self-archived immediately upon publication anyway, or after a six month embargo, including uploaded to PubMed Central. That means all the peer-reviewed science, minus the fancy […]

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/a-challenge-to-publishers-to-justify-embargo-periods/#comment-558">paulsturgess</a>.
Because it is part of the formally 'required' process in order to receive recognition for your work.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to paulsturgess.

Because it is part of the formally ‘required’ process in order to receive recognition for your work.

item.title: By: paulsturgess
item.dc:creator: paulsturgess
item.description: if they (the publishers) add little or no value to your article, then why are you bothering to submit your work to them it in first place?
item.content:encoded: if they (the publishers) add little or no value to your article, then why are you bothering to submit your work to them it in first place?

item.title: By: Malcolm Smith
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Smith
item.description: Seems a similar approach to commercial publishing, where the more expensive hardback is always out in the shops before a cheaper paperback. If you *really* want it, you'll pay for it!
item.content:encoded: Seems a similar approach to commercial publishing, where the more expensive hardback is always out in the shops before a cheaper paperback. If you *really* want it, you’ll pay for it!

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/a-challenge-to-publishers-to-justify-embargo-periods/#comment-555">Jan H. Jensen</a>.
But do they own copyright over the AAM or pre- or post-print versions of an article? I still want them to defend themselves. "Because we can" is a crap response, if that's all they have.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jan H. Jensen.

But do they own copyright over the AAM or pre- or post-print versions of an article? I still want them to defend themselves. “Because we can” is a crap response, if that’s all they have.

item.title: By: Jan H. Jensen
item.dc:creator: Jan H. Jensen
item.description: As long as the publishers own the copyright, they don't have to defend anything they don't feel like regarding their property.
item.content:encoded: As long as the publishers own the copyright, they don’t have to defend anything they don’t feel like regarding their property.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/a-challenge-to-publishers-to-justify-embargo-periods/#comment-553">brembs</a>.
Cool, thanks, Bjoern!

item.title: By: brembs
item.dc:creator: brembs
item.description: Publisher representatives have already admitted they add no value: http://bjoern.brembs.net/2013/10/no-need-for-the-publishers-authorized-version/
item.content:encoded:
Publisher representatives have already admitted they add no value:
http://bjoern.brembs.net/2013/10/no-need-for-the-publishers-authorized-version/
